Richard Boyle.Action: Rocks and feeds the crying baby handed to him by Claudia during a heated argument.
Begins to plead with the landlord to delay eviction despite the landlord’s hostility.
Tries to soothe Claudia when she is upset and promises to get money to calm her down.
Denies drinking and tries to reassure Claudia despite evidence to the contrary.
Appears dismissive and irresponsible with money and work commitments, causing frustration for colleagues.
Attempts to justify his previous work successes and promises good future work despite past failures.
Asks Larry for financial help urgently to return to El Salvador, showing vulnerability and reliance on a friend.
Dismisses Larry's concern with impatience, focusing only on getting money, showing little tolerance for caution.
Pleading with police officer and attempting to appeal to his humanity when being arrested.
Thanks Doctor Rock for bailing him out of jail.
Shows concern about Bagel being in jail but seems resigned and cynical about his friends ('friends, hah').
Complains bitterly about his own hardships (lost job, eviction, wife leaving, no money to feed kids).
Dismisses and judges Miriam's wishes and yuppie women in a derogatory manner.
Shows empathy towards Doc's situation by offering him a joint and sharing his own housing troubles.
Scratches his allergies and appears somewhat detached during Doc's distress over the dog being put down.
Attempts to console or move on from Doc's grief by saying 'She can't do anything. Come on...'
Asks about his missing dog and reacts emotionally but does not appear to take any action to prevent or cope effectively with the loss.
Acknowledges their eviction situation honestly and communicates it to Doc.
Scratches his allergies during a stressful moment instead of focusing on problem solving.
Offers another joint to Doc, showing some social and coping behavior under stress.
Expresses feeling totally alone in the world, emphasizing lack of family or responsibilities.
Half-listens to Doc's complaints, seeming somewhat detached.
Shows casual confidence and shares a knowing look with Doc during roulette bet.
Plans to go to Guatemala citing freedom and amenities, including seeking out a whorehouse.
Sells his car to quickly get $1000 cash and immediately bets the entire amount on red at roulette, showing casual confidence in high-risk gambling.
Plans to go to Guatemala citing no cops, no laws, and cheap pleasures, demonstrating a bold but reckless and possibly naive strategy.
Drives recklessly at 100 mph in a severely damaged car, with doors wired on and no muffler.
Attempts to reassure and convince Doc about the dangers and realities of El Salvador, showing some persuasive skills.
Plans to take combat photos to sell to AP to raise money for a future getaway, showing some strategic thinking about his goals.
Lies repeatedly to Doc, including about the destination and situation, undermining trust and practical judgment.
Gives cyanide pills to Doc and urges him to hide and 'be cool,' showing care for his friend's safety despite the danger.
Attempts friendly interaction with the rebel honcho using fake Spanish and smiles despite threat, indicating social adaptability and an effort to avoid conflict.
Frantically checks pockets and prepares for worst-case scenario, reflecting anxiety but also concern for himself and companions.
Frantically checks pockets for cyanide pills and tries to prepare for the worst at the roadblock, giving one pill to Doc.
Uses broken Spanish to try to bluff the armed roadblock, smiling and acting friendly despite obvious danger.
Appears drunk and reliant on substances (tequila, joint), which may impair judgment in a tense situation.
Tries to negotiate or talk down prices, suggesting some street savvy, but not necessarily competence in a serious context.
Advises Doc to fight back and not get down on the ground during the robbery to protect themselves.
Agitated but tries to stay calm and protect Doc during a threatening situation.
Seizes an opportunity to appeal to a higher authority (Smiling Death) to protect them, showing quick thinking to safeguard others.
Worriedly advises to fight and run instead of getting down when threatened by armed men, showing situational awareness and survival instincts.
Attempts to save himself and his companion by seizing an opportunity to identify himself and wave his press credentials to a National Guard lieutenant, demonstrating quick thinking under threat.
Despite the danger, stays partially composed and tries to use his status as a journalist to avoid harm, indicating presence of mind in a hostile situation.
Shows underlying agitation under his smile and internally curses his misfortune, possibly reflecting anxiety and lack of full control over the situation.
Explains to Rock the significance of the cedula system calmly, showing some patience and effort to inform.
Forcibly marched and detained but shows no visible panic, tries to reassure Rock by saying he knows Colonel Figueroa.
Explains the significance of 'cedulas' to Rock, showing knowledge of local documents required to avoid trouble.
Attempts to use his connection by shouting he is a good friend of Colonel Figueroa while being detained.
Is forced to comply and is helpless as soldiers detain him and an innocent kid is beaten publicly, showing lack of control in the situation.
Fails to prevent or influence the violent outcome witnessed (the shooting of the kid) despite being present and having some connections.
Hurries Rock along past the corpse without showing empathy.
Shares a grim laugh acknowledging danger but keeps spirits light.
Snuck into the military quarters despite explicit forbidding, showing resourcefulness but disregarding rules.
Hugs Colonel Figueroa warmly on unexpected meeting.

Fingers his cyanide pill, showing awareness of the danger and contingency planning.

Passively receives a lot of critical intelligence about the unstable political and military situation without taking discernible initiative or showing clear strategic response.
Observes the scene carefully, indicating some level of situational awareness and gathering information.
Kicks Rock under the table after Rock reacts disgusted by dried ears on the table.

Requests to go out with a recon unit to get good combat shots, showing engagement and eagerness rather than hostility.

Quickly loading three cameras and four lenses at a table, appearing practiced and efficient as a war correspondent.

Fishes out his own bottle of Tic-tac to explain the cause of the problem with the 'Tic-tac monster', showing an attempt to address the issue.

Shows frustration and anger at the situation, but does not effectively manage it, leading to escalating chaos.

Does not shoot film at the gruesome bodies, showing sensitivity and respect towards Cassady's work rather than intruding.

Responds calmly and listens to the Spook's warning, showing openness.
Turns his back on a protesting man being hustled out by plainclothesmen, showing disregard for the disturbance.
Politely refuses to join a peace vigil invited by a missionary, indicating a lack of engagement with local socio-political events.
Listens to a 'Spook' giving a warning and takes it seriously, showing some situational awareness and caution.
Responds affirmatively and prepares to move quickly after Cassady informs him about the military offensive starting, showing readiness and responsiveness.
Joyfully plays with his children, picks up and swings his daughter, who giggles.
Shows intense, frantic affection and need toward Maria, holding her as if she might fly away if let go.
Makes a sudden, secretive stop in Libertad, leaving Cassady behind reluctantly.
Insists on making a quick stop in Libertad despite the risk of losing time.
Leaves quickly with Cassady despite possible logistical drawbacks, showing decisiveness.
Arrives at Maria’s shack urgently and shows deep emotional engagement, suggesting personal priorities over mission focus.
Appears deeply distracted and emotionally vulnerable, potentially risking mission focus.
Joins Cassady in raising a white flag to signal journalists and avoid conflict.
Rushes with Cassady into a dangerous situation to help and document the plight of trapped National Guardsmen.
Racing his car confidently towards a rebel-controlled roadblock and successfully negotiating safe passage by following protocol and cooperating with armed men.
Deciding with Cassady to enter a dangerous Police bunker to get a story despite the obvious risk, showing calculated courage and situational awareness.
Remaining calm and communicating clearly with frightened National Guardsmen, instantly becoming a symbol of hope and help.
Pulls Cassady out of the fire zone to protect him from danger.
Runs over to intervene as a National Guardsman is pleading for his life, tries to stop Gabriella from shooting him.
Gives up his camera to pass by the rebel preventing him from photographing the executions.
Reloads cameras quickly and prepares to keep filming under heavy fire and chaotic conditions.
Attempts to take pictures against rebel instructions and is grabbed before he can intervene, showing limited ability to control the situation.
Turns away disgustedly from the violence and grabs Rafael to confront him about justice.
Packs his medical kit to presumably provide aid amid the conflict.
Gets great shots amidst heavy fire from enemy tanks and infantry.
His camera's advance lever breaks off, rendering the camera useless; he kicks himself in frustration, feeling like he missed the greatest shots of his lifetime.
Yelling warnings to others in danger (telling people to get down).
Screams in anguish at seeing a colleague mortally wounded.
Despite being wounded himself, drags himself painfully toward his injured colleague.
Performs a crude, emergency tracheotomy on a dying Cassady in an effort to save him.
Performs a crude emergency tracheotomy on Cassady to help him breathe.
Performs mouth to mouth resuscitation on Cassady and listens closely to his last whispered words.
Reassures Cassady by promising to get the film to New York and praises him.
Buries his face in his hands in a moment of grief after Cassady’s death.
Performs a crude, emergency tracheotomy on Cassady to help him breathe.
Performs mouth-to-mouth resuscitation on Cassady and listens carefully to his final words, showing focus and care.
Quickly takes possession of Cassady's blood-soaked camera and reassures him, showing a sense of responsibility.
Buries his face in his hands after Cassady's death, indicating an emotional reaction that may momentarily affect his professional composure.
Encourages John Cassady by telling him he got the magic shot and is the best.
Buried his face in his hands, tuning out the chaos and the scene around him.
Buries his face in his hands after a traumatic event, tunes out chaos while being evacuated in a litter.
Encourages and praises John Cassady for getting the key shot despite the danger.
Asks casually 'who's winning the war man?' despite the serious situation and his injury.
Calls doctor a dumb shit and yells for a painkiller while in pain.
Sees military situation and sarcastically comments on 'real vultures'.
Drinks whiskey while enduring pain and surgery, shows raw, unfiltered behavior.
Grips Maria's hand seeking comfort in a painful moment.
Curses aggressively at the medical staff in frustration and pain.
Grips Maria's hand while feeling woozy and very sick, showing connection and concern despite his own pain.
Advises Doc to stay safe, not become dependent on drugs, and warns him about dangers, showing care and sincerity.
Gives Doc a heartfelt look after Doc sarcastically thanks him, showing genuine warmth despite sarcasm.
Shows awareness of the dangerous situation and instructs Doc on what to do upon arrival, emphasizing caution and communication.
Despite being very sick, heavily medicated, and barely able to keep control of the car, continues to drive the group toward the border, pushing through physical limits.
Takes a big swig of Tic-tac (painkillers), eyes getting woozy, indicating possible overreliance on medication impacting alertness.
Attempts to use humor and encouragement with Doc, advising caution not to become a 'Tic-tac monster' and warning about dangers, showing some emotional intelligence and leadership.
Shares a fearful, dismayed look with Maria when confronted with fake visa accusation
Attempts to explain and justify himself nervously when caught with fake visa
Looks at his fake gold wristwatch and removes it before quickly ushering Maria and the kids out of a dangerous situation
Leaves behind his watch and hurries Maria and the children away, ensuring their safety amid escalating tension
Mentions a meeting with Ambassador White and friend Napoleon, possibly fabricating an excuse to leave
Crosses himself sincerely before attempting to commit suicide, showing vulnerability and seriousness.
Expresses anger and curses at Pedro for the failed execution attempt, showing impatience and harshness.
Interacts jovially with guardsmen, drinks beer with Pedro, accepts gifts, sharing light moments despite grim circumstances.
Is warmly embraced by Maria and kids, indicating they trust and care for him, suggesting his warmth towards them.
Buys a gift for Duglas, interacts casually with Maria and kids playing American culture roles, showing friendly and caring behavior.
Calmly crosses himself and swallows a cyanide pill while facing imminent death, showing resolve and control.
Gets angry and insults Pedro for not loading the rifle properly in a tense life-or-death moment.
Maintains composure after the failed execution attempt, then adapts to new circumstances and interacts amicably with captors and friends.
Engages in lighthearted behavior (drinking beer, exchanging jokes, buying gifts for friends and family) shortly after near-death experience.
Takes wife and kids on a day trip to Nogales, interacts affectionately and reassuringly in Spanish with Maria, embraces her warmly, expresses hope things will get better.
Successfully gets through a not particularly tight checkpoint quickly using his press card, appearing unbothered and managing his family at the same time.
Plans to sell stories on Salvador and shows cautious optimism about things working out.
Appears somewhat bored and distracted (shifting bags, busy) during crossing, possibly not fully engaged or alert to surroundings.
Grips Maria's hand, tries to protect her from Immigration Officer, insists she is his wife and assistant, stands up to authority to defend her.
Physically assaults Immigration Officer by chopping him in face and ribs.
Freaks out and threatens the officer aggressively instead of calmly explaining the situation.
Hands over press card but fails to deescalate the situation or prevent arrest.
Physically attacks the officer, trying to protect Maria and the kids, showing some courage but poor judgment.
Fails to anticipate the presence of multiple officers and the likelihood of escalation, leading to both him and Maria being handcuffed.
Screams at the cops, desperately pleading to save Maria and the children from harm.
Physically confronts authority by yelling and escalating the situation, resulting in being punched and arrested.
Shows emotional vulnerability and despair when seeing Maria and the children being taken away, which impairs his effectiveness.
Shows a stunned look, appears lost and alone with tears in his eyes.
Appears stunned, lost, and alone with tears in his eyes.
